metadata.title: Preparation and Tribological properties of novel Boehmite/Graphene Oxide nano-hybrid

sections.text:
Novel boehmite/graphene oxide nano-hybrid (GO-GPTS-AlOOH) was prepared through a simple covalent bond method, which was subsequently explored as lubricant additive. For this purpose, the 3-glycidoxypropyl-trimethoxysilane (GPTS) was first chemically grafted on nano-boehmite (AlOOH) to fabricate the modified boehmite (GPTS-AlOOH). Then the GPTS-AlOOH was anchored on graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets to prepare GO-GPTS-AlOOH nano-hybrid through a coupled reaction. The structure, composition and morphology of GO-GPTS-AlOOH was characterized by FT-IR, XRD, TG/DTG, SEM and TEM, revealing that nano-boehmite was uniformly coated on GO surface. More importantly, tribological properties of GO-GPTS-AlOOH as lubricating oil additive were investigated using a ball-on-disc testing machine and a four-ball machine. It was found that the friction reduction and anti-wear ability of lubricant oil containing GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid was highly improved compared to bare base oil (VHVI8). Specifically, friction coefficient (COF), wear scar diameter (WSD) and wear rate were reduced by 14%, 28% and 73%, respectively. The enhancement can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the nanobearing mechanism and ultimate strengthen of graphene sheets between the frictional interfaces.
Key words: graphene oxide, boehmite, 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane, lubricant, friction reduction, anti-wear
1. Introduction
Graphene, a two-dimensional honeycomb lattice of sp 2 bonded carbon atoms, has attracted a lot of interests from all over the world due to its unique structure and excellent properties [1-5]. Owing to its remarkable mechanical, optical, electrical and thermal properties, graphene has been regarded as the most promising nanomaterial in many fields. For example, graphene has been incorporated in composite materials and dispersed throughout the matrix for use in electronics field [6-11]. Moreover, the two-dimension nano-material is considered as an excellent candidate for various applications in energy-storage materials [12, 13], liquid crystal devices [14] and in the bio field [15].
It is well-known that friction and wear are the main causes of energy consumption and material losses [16, 17]. Recently, many researches have been focusing on the tribological properties of graphene owing to its excellent chemical and physical properties such as ultrathin structure, high thermal stability, ultra-smooth surface and ultimate mechanical strength [1, 18-21]. Like some other layered materials (i.e. MoS2, WS2 and hexagonal BN) used as lubricant additives [22-25], graphene has exhibited great prospect in lube oil industry.
However, uniform and stable dispersion of graphene in base oil are the two key issues needed to be considered for graphene or graphene oxide-based effective lubricant additive. To solve these problems, several procedures have been developed.
Oleic and stearic acids modified graphene have been found to improve the friction-reduction property, wear-resistance and load-bearing capacity of lube oil due to their small size and extremely thin laminated structure [26, 27]. Khatri et al. [28] have reported 26% and 9% reduction in frictional coefficient and wear scar diameter, respectively, with octadecylamine functionalized graphene oxide as lubricant additive into hexadecane. Song et al. [29] have synthesized α-Fe2O3 nanorod/graphene oxide composites through a facile hydrolysis and annealing route. The anchoring α-Fe2O3 nanorod onto GO nanosheets was explained as the intercalation and adsorption of iron ions on GO surface. Furthermore, the α-Fe2O3/GO composites were easily dispersed into base oil and highly improved the anti-wear and friction reduction abilities of the base oil with a small dose. Recently, Ramaprabhu et al. [30] have performed a versatile method for production of ultra-thin graphene without any functional groups, which demonstrated excellent friction reduction and anti-wear properties, using solar exfoliation technique.
Herein, we developed a novel procedure to inhibit the agglomeration and improved dispersion stability of graphene sheets (GO-GPTS-AlOOH) in base oil. Nano-boehmite (AlOOH), which has been mass-produced in industry, is commercially available. Moreover, the AlOOH can be directly modified by GPTS without any chemical pretreatment due to the massive hydroxyl groups on its surface. Specifically, AlOOH was covalently functionalized with GPTS followed by anchoring on the surface of GO. The structure and stacking state of GO-GPTS-AlOOH were confirmed by FT-IR, XRD, TG/DTG, SEM and TEM. Then the tribological properties of GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid were investigated as additive in lubricant base oil (VHVI8). The results showed that the tribological properties, which were characterized by average coefficient of friction (COF) and wear scar diameter (WSD),
were significantly improved. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Raman spectrum were performed to analyze the wear scar surfaces after friction. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report about the application of GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid as oil-based lubricant additive.
2. Experimental Section
2.1. Preparation of GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrids
Graphene oxide(GO), an intermediate material, was prepared from natural graphite powder by the modified Hummer’s method [31, 32] Briefly, 0.8 g of graphite powder was oxidized with 24 mL of concentrated H2SO4 and 5 g of KMnO4 in ice-water bath. Then the mixture was stirred at 39 ℃ for 2 h. Distilled water (41 mL) was gradually dropped into the above solution and heated to 98 ℃. This reaction was ended with 120 mL of 10% H2O2. The mixture was separated by repeated centrifugation and filtration until sulfate ion could not be detected with BaCl2. Finally, the black powder was dried in a vacuum oven at 60 ℃ for 24 h to obtain GO nanosheets.
As for GPTS-AlOOH (AlOOH functionalized with GPTS), 1 g of nano-AlOOH was dispersed into 100 mL of anhydrous ethanol, followed by gradual addition of 2 g KH560. The mixture was treated under the protection of nitrogen while stirring at room temperature for 10h. Then the prepared GPTS-AlOOH nanoparticle was thoroughly washed with ethanol and then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 ℃ for 24 h.
The synthesis procedure of GO–GPTS-AlOOH hybrid was illustrated in Scheme 1. Simply, the GPTS-AlOOH (0.5g) was dispersed in 100 mL distilled water with ultrasonic treatment for 30 minutes. Then 60 mL of solution containing GO (0.1g) was added drop by drop. The reaction mixture was stirred and refluxed for 10h at 85 ℃, and the product obtained was filtered, washed, and dried 24 h at 60 ℃ in a vacuum oven.
2.2. Characterization of GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid
Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of GO, AlOOH, GPTS-AlOOH and GO– GPTS-AlOOH samples were characterized using infrared spectroscopy（FTIR, WQF-520, Rayleigh）with KBr pellets as the sample matrix. The crystal structure of these particles were recorded by X-ray diffraction (XRD) with Cu Kα radiation source using a Thermo ESCALAB 250 instrument (PANalytical, Netherlands). The diffraction data were recorded for a 2θ angle between 2° and 80° at a scan rate of 2°·min -1 . Thermogravimetric analysis (TG/DTG) of the samples was carried out to identify the chemical reaction during the preparation process, using a TG209F1 thermal analyzer (Netzsch, Germany), with the temperature ranging from 20 to 1000 ℃ at a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. The morphology of tested sample surfaces were carried out by SEM (JSM-7500F, Japan) at 20 kV. TEM measurements were conducted on a JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV.
2.3. Lubrication properties test
Several nano-lubricants containing different concentrations of GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid was prepared. The lubrication properties of hydroisomerization base oil (VHVI8) with and without GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid were characterized in terms of frictional coefficient (COF) and wear scar test. The frictional coefficient (COF) was measured using a ball-on-disk tribometer (MS-T3000, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, China) in the rotating mode. In COF test experiment, 100Cr6 steel ball (ø=6.35mm) was used as the stationary upper counterparts, while the lower disc was mounted on a rotating table. All experiments were carried out at a consistent load of 10N and a linear speed of 5 cm/s for 4000 laps. Then 5 mL of lubricant was applied to ensure that the sliding interfaces were always covered. Then anti-wear properties of VHVI8 without and with additives wear evaluated in terms of wear scar test, using a four-ball test machine (Jinan assaying Group, China) (Fig. 1). Briefly, the wear scar test was carried out under a load of 392N at a rotating speed of 600rpm for a test duration of 60min at a temperature of 75 ℃(ASTM st andard D 5183). The tester was operated with one steel ball (ø=12.7mm) under load rotating against the three lower steel balls (ø=12.7mm), which were locked together in the holder and covered with the oil samples.
3. Result and discussion
3.1 IR analysis
FTIR spectra of intermediate and target products are showed in Fig. 2. The bands of
3290 and 3091 cm -1 are assigned to the stretching vibration of O-H. They both decrease with the treatment of GPTS on boehmite. The vibration modes of nitrate/carbonate contamination at 1638 and 1384 cm -1 , which are ascribed to the preparation procedure of boehmite, almost disappear after GPTS treatment [33, 34]. The bands in the region of 1000-1200 cm -1 , which are assigned to Si–O–Si asymmetric stretching, Si–O–R stretching and CH3 rocking vibration [35-37] increase dramatically in intensity. Also the intensity of band observed at 909 cm -1 (due the Si– OH stretching) increases with the functionalization of GPTS on boehmite. Furthermore, no characteristic peak can be clearly assigned to Si–O–Al mode [35]. In summary, the interaction can be inferred from the decreasing of the peaks at 3290 and 3091 cm -1 (due to the O–H on boehmite surface).
The IR spectrum of GO presents the following characteristic peaks: peak at 3350
cm -1 attributed to the O–H stretching vibration of the C–OH groups, the 1621 cm -1 assigned to the C=O stretching vibration of the -COOH groups, a strong band at 1379 cm -1 assigned to the O–H deformation of the C–OH groups, and a strong band at 1060 cm -1 attributed to C=O stretching vibration, peak at about 1731 cm -1 comes from stretching of the carbonyl groups (–COOH).
Compared with GPTS-AlOOH and GO, the spectrum of GO-GPTS-AlOOH shows
several variations. The strong band from 3000 to 3700cm -1 (containing stretching vibration of O-H in –COOH) and peak at 1731 cm -1 almost disappear. For
GPTS-AlOOH, the band at 909 cm -1 vanishes in the same way. Therefore, the condensation reaction between GO (–COOH) and hydrolysate of GPTS (–SiOH) could be confirmed. Moreover, the peaks at 2923 and 2854cm -1 are still existed. All these results indicate that the target product (GO-GPTS-AlOOH) has been successfully prepared according to method illustrated in Scheme 1.
3.2 XRD analysis
XRD patterns of GO, AlOOH, GPTS-AlOOH and GO–GPTS-AlOOH samples were measured to probe their stacking state. As clearly observed in Fig. 3, both AlOOH and GPTS-AlOOH samples show almost identical diffractograms, stemming from the characteristic diffraction peak of orthorhombic Boehmite phase (ICDD no. 98-009-2910) [38]. The newly presented weak and broad peak around 2θ=20.50° of GPTS-AlOOH indicates the presence of an amorphous phase originating from the GPTS [35]. Simultaneously, the diffraction peaks of GPTS-AlOOH are also observed in the XRD pattern of GO–GPTS-AlOOH, revealing successful grafting of GPTS-AlOOH hybrid on the GO surface. The GO depicts a strong and broad diffraction peak at 2θ=10.96° with a corresponding d-spacing of ～0.81 nm, which is due to the presence of oxygen functionalities in the basal plane of natural graphite [39]. However, the loading of GPTS-AlOOH on GO makes an obvious change in XRD pattern. The disappearance of peak near 10.96° in GO–GPTS-AlOOH reveals that the nano-AlOOH has successfully coated on basal plane of GO sheets.
3.3 TG/DTG analysis
Thermogravimetry tests were carried out to detect the thermal decomposition property of as prepared hybrids in the TG/TGA instrument from 20 to 1000 ℃ under flowing N2. Fig. 4 shows the TG/DTG curves of AlOOH, GPTS-AlOOH, GO and GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid. GO suffers an apparent loss near 100 °C due to the loss of adsorbed water in the samples. Subsequently, the major mass loss of GO at ~220 °C is accompanied by a vigorous release of gas, which is attributed to CO, CO2, and steam release from labile functional groups[40, 41], resulting in a rapid thermal expansion of the powder material and large mass loss (flying GO sheets in the TGA instrument) [42]. There is also a slower mass loss observed from 400 to 950°C that can be attributed to the removal of more stable oxygen functionalities [43].The TG curve of pure AlOOH shows almost the same trend that observed by Kololuoma et al. [38], containing the desorption process of absorbed water around 100 ℃ and transition of AlOOH to γ-alumina from 200 to 500 ℃ The corresponding 15% mass loss due to the conversion of AlOOH to γ-alumina can be explained by the work of Alphonse et al. [44].
The weight loss between 270 and 510 ℃ is about 13 wt% for AlOOH and about 34 wt% for GPTS-AlOOH. This gap confirms that GPTS has been successfully grafted on AlOOH surface [38]. Compared with GO, the mass loss of GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrids around 100 ℃decreases sharply from 18% to 3%, suggesting that less water is adsorbed in GO-GPTS-AlOOH samples. It can be related
to the condensation reaction between hydrophilic group (-COOH) of GO and hydrolysate of GPTS (–SiOH), which is consistent with the earlier statement in IR analysis. Nevertheless, there is more absorbed water in GO-GPTS-AlOOH than that in GPTS-AlOOH, which can be inferred from the ungrafted hydrophilic groups such as hydroxy and epoxy groups in GO sheets.
3.4 Morphology analysis of GO-GPTS-AlOOH
The morphology and microstructure of GO and GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid were detected by SEM and TEM instruments. As shown in Fig. 5a and c, the lamellar structure and transparence of GO can be clearly observed. However, GO nanosheets still aggregate and demonstrate a stacking state, which can be attributed to their high specific area. Accordingly, the lamellar structure of GO-GPTS-AlOOH is also depicted in Fig. 5b with the GO surface becoming rougher than that in Fig. 5a. This change may be due to the successful graft of nano-AlOOH on GO, which can be confirmed in the TEM image of GO-GPTS-AlOOH (Fig. 5d). Apparently, the nano-AlOOH particles are uniformly distributed on GO surface, thereby preventing GO sheets from coagulating. This is proposed to ensure the interposition of nanosheets into friction pairs.
3.5 Tribological and lubrication characterization
Different concentrations of GO-GPTS-AlOOH dispersed in VHVI8 (48h after ultrasonic treatment) are shown in Fig. 6a, suggesting the stability of the nanofluids. The right inset (Fig. 6b) confirms the hydrophobicity of GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid.
Friction coefficient (COF) of GO-GPTS-AlOOH as additive to hydroisomerization
base oil (VHVI8) was measured using a ball-on-disc test machine under a load of 10N. Fig. 7a shows the changes of COF with time and Fig. 7b shows the average friction coefficient for different concentrations of GO-GPTS-AlOOH in VHVI8. VHVI8, which is considered to be a high quality base oil and commercially available, exhibits ∼0.111 friction coefficient. The COF is gradually reduced with increasing dose of GO–GPTS-AlOOH and then it increases with further increasing dose of GO– GPTS-AlOOH. The lowest COF (~0.095) found at a concentration of 0.030 mg·mL -1 is reduced by ~14% compared to pure VHVI8. However, the COF climbs up as the concentration of GO–GPTS-AlOOH increases continuously and even exceeds that of pure VHVI8. This can be attributed to the abrasive effect of higher concentration of GO–GPTS-AlOOH between the contact interfaces. Consequently, there is a higher resistance to shear and that increases the friction [24, 45].
Wear scar diameter (WSD) results measured by four ball machine test are shown in Fig. 7c. It is clear that WSD decreases as the GO–GPTS-AlOOH concentration increases in VHVI8 base oil. Compared to pure VHVI8, WSD of 0.030 mg·mL -1 concentration reduces significantly from 0.582 mm to 0.418 mm (about 28% decline), which is accompanied by a corresponding variation trend of wear rate from 2.22×10-6 to 0.590×10-6 mm3·N-1·min-1 (about 73% decline). The worn scar images of lower steel balls are shown in Fig. 8. The worn surface
lubricated by bare base oil (Fig. 8a, c) shows deeper scratches and grooves than that protected by base oil containing GO–GPTS-AlOOH (Fig. 8b, d). This suggests that the boundary lubricating film is more efficient with GO–GPTS-AlOOH sheets.
3.6 Lubrication mechanism
In this work, it is shown that with the presence of GO–GPTS-AlOOH, the friction reduction and anti-wear ability of base oil VHVI8 have been significantly improved. Meanwhile, a very low friction coefficient has been obtained. It is proposed that the GO–GPTS-AlOOH nanosheets can easily enter the interfaces of frictional pairs due to the intrinsic lamellar structure of graphene, avoiding direct contact between rotating balls. Song et al. demonstrated that the anti-wear ability of liquid paraffin was highly improved with α-Fe2O3 nanorod/graphene oxide composites [29]. Furthermore, once the GO–GPTS-AlOOH insert, it can act as a nano-bearing and friction coefficient is consequently reduced. To understand the role of GO–GPTS-AlOOH, Raman spectra was performed on the worn surfaces (Fig. 8e, f), which were lubricated by VHVI8 base oil without and with 0.030 mg·mL -1 GO–GPTS-AlOOH nanosheets. It is clearly demonstrated in Fig. 8f that the two characteristic peaks of graphene at 1300 cm -1 (D) band and 1567 cm -1 (G) band were detected on the worn area lubricated with GO– GPTS-AlOOH. The disorder (D) band responds to defects and edges carbon while the (G) band represents regular graphene skeleton, revealing the adhesion of graphene sheets on wear tracks [46, 47]. However, there is no Raman signal on the wear scar lubricated with bare oil (Fig.8 e). According to these results, the speculations about friction reduction and wear resistance in previous analyses can be further confirmed. Specifically, the presence of GO–GPTS-AlOOH not only bears the high load but also separates the rubbing faces. The internal shear in the deposited thin films of GO– GPTS-AlOOH and slide over the dispersed nanosheets under the contact stress has reduced the friction and protected the contact interfaces from damage, according with the results reported by Pan et al. [48].
4. Conclusions
The GO–GPTS-AlOOH hybrid has been prepared through a coupled reaction using GO, GPTS and AlOOH. Herein, nano-boehmite was successfully anchored on the surface of GO sheets, as revealed by the FTIR, XRD, TG/DTG and TEM methods. Then nano-lubricants with different concentration of GO–GPTS-AlOOH was blended. Due to the van der Waals interaction between oelophilic groups of GPTS and hydrocarbon groups of hydroisomerization dewax base oil, GO–GPTS-AlOOH sheets was homogenously mixed in VHVI8. The tribological results suggest that the lubricity by reducing the friction and wear parameters of VHVI8 was significantly developed with minute dosage of GO–GPTS-AlOOH. The SEM and Raman characterizations performed on worn surfaces affirm that GO sheets have smoothly entered the contact surfaces with the oil and slide between the friction pairs, bearing the load of steel ball and preventing damage.

metadata.abstractText: Novel boehmite/graphene oxide nano-hybrid (GO-GPTS-AlOOH) was prepared through a simple covalent bond method, which was subsequently explored as lubricant additive. For this purpose, the 3-glycidoxypropyl-trimethoxysilane (GPTS) was first chemically grafted on nano-boehmite (AlOOH) to fabricate the modified boehmite (GPTS-AlOOH). Then the GPTS-AlOOH was anchored on graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets to prepare GO-GPTS-AlOOH nano-hybrid through a coupled reaction. The structure, composition and morphology of GO-GPTS-AlOOH was characterized by FT-IR, XRD, TG/DTG, SEM and TEM, revealing that nano-boehmite was uniformly coated on GO surface. More importantly, tribological properties of GO-GPTS-AlOOH as lubricating oil additive were investigated using a ball-on-disc testing machine and a four-ball machine. It was found that the friction reduction and anti-wear ability of lubricant oil containing GO-GPTS-AlOOH hybrid was highly improved compared to bare base oil (VHVI8). Specifically, friction coefficient (COF), wear scar diameter (WSD) and wear rate were reduced by 14%, 28% and 73%, respectively. The enhancement can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the nanobearing mechanism and ultimate strengthen of graphene sheets between the frictional interfaces.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
